title: Redbrook Reservoir Walking Route

images.title: Alexander P Kapp / Redbrook Reservoir
images.caption: Redbrook Reservoir. Small feeder reservoir for the Huddersfield Narrow Canal.

images.title: John Illingworth / Redbrook Reservoir
images.caption: Looking north-east over the lake towards Pule Hill.

images.title: John Illingworth / View from Pule Hill with paraglider
images.caption: Standedge from Pule Hill. The A62 road across the Pennines at Standedge, in a view seen from the top of Pule Hill looking west. The Standedge cutting and Redbrook reservoir can be seen.

images.title: Skirting Warcock Hill by Bill Boaden, CC BY-SA 2.0 <https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/2.0>, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: Skirting Warcock Hill

images.title: The outlet to Black Moss Reservoir by Humphrey Bolton, CC BY-SA 2.0 <https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/2.0>, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: The outlet to Black Moss Reservoir

description: This walk visits Redbrook Reservoir and Black Moss Reservoir in Kirklees. There's some roadside parking at the northern end of the lake. You can then follow footpaths south east to link up with the Standedge Trail. Follow the trail west and it will take you past Warcock Hill before turning south east to visit Black Moss Reservoir and Swellands Reservoir. The route then returns to the start point on the same paths. You can extend the walk by heading north to Marsden Moor and climbing Pule Hill for some fine views over the area. March Haigh Reservoir and the fine viewpoint at Buckstone Edge can also be found on the moor.
